reviewText:
In a fantasy world, in order to prevent the dark forces from destroying it, students are taught in numerous combat methods and become ninjas. The story focuses on the four main player characters, who share some rather humorous interactions during the course of their adventure to destroy the numerous bosses (I know its a generic term, but thats basically what they are) to protect the land. Anyway, summary over, on to the review!
This game is enjoyable, I will be finishing this game. So, you may be wondering why I am giving this a negative review.

Personally, I do not think the game, in it's current state, is publishing worthy. I am not just saying this because it is a RPG Maker Game, I actually am adept at using RPG Maker and applaud the creators of this game for attempting to publish it. So I have some words of advice for the creators of this game. If you are going to post a RPG Maker Game, unless it has custom materials, forget about it. The major let down for me during my playing time is the lack of unique, custom assets. Anyone that has either played to many RPG Maker Games or has used the program itself will not find the use of default materials exciting. I liked the comical aspects of the story and characters, but when compared to other similar games, it is still lacking. I know how hard it is to make a game that can be competitive in this market, but I have high hopes that with some changes, this game could become something. Having created numerous RPG Maker games (none of which I have published/monitized), I know the efforts that go into making one of a large scale. So, to review what I have said concerning what this game needs...
-Custom Material is the most important thing. Using a example map with a few small changes isn't going to make it. Also, although sound doesn't seem all to important, the right sounds can make or brake a game. Although some of the sounds work, I would suggest changing up a little for variety.

There are some things that I did find interesting, and think is a job well done...
-Menus. The menus were actually very nice, well edited and so on. Some of the menu designs look similar/exact to some that I have found online, which is fine, as long as you have recieved proper permissions to use them (if applicable).
-Combat system, although not overally so impressed. The combat is a basic sideview battler system, so that does seperate it from the typical first person battle view. Might I ask though, did you create the battle system yourselves, or did you use one of the common online scripts such as Yanfly's Battle System (I hope I named it right, I haven't used RPG Maker in a while, so I have forgotten a lot of the script providers names).

In short, the game is not of the level where I think it should be monitized. I have personally created games that are on par or better than this one (based on unique materials, custom scripts, so on), and even those I would not feel confident enough about to publish commercially. I do intend to beat this game, and will most likely enjoy doing so, but overall I cannot approve of this game. I applaud the developers on their work, but this game is just lacks the uniqueness that games like this desperately need.

May your adventures be many and always end in reward!
-Donoknight, Guildmaster of the Tabletop RPG Gamers League
Note to the Developers: If you have any questions concerning my review or need any help concerning the future plans/changes to this game, I am happy to help in whatever way I can to help this game thrive in this competitive market.

If you value your sanity stay far away from this game.

Disclaimer: I was generously given a free copy of Destiny Warriors with the understanding that I was expected to review the title after spending some time with it.

Steam really does not need more RPG Maker viscera. I’m beginning to feel like that tool was one of the worst things to happen to the marketplace since anime visual novels. With that said, what is good about Destiny Warrior?

Well the art style is actually quite charming; it keeps the appeal of simple pixel art with just enough polish to keep it from looking like garbage on a 1080p monitor at fullscreen. The combat has very pretty effects and in my opinion are decently animated. The music is certainly generic but far from the obnoxious noise I’ve had to mute in some other RPG Maker titles I’ve experienced recently. You also receive a rating post-combat that can give you bonus gold and experience which I thought was actually really cool. The interface, however, is difficult to read due to an over use of pastel colors and this also makes figuring out who the active character in combat is.

It works, but it’s one of a million of these RPG Maker excretions. Do yourself a favor: if you like what you visually, go get a copy of Chrono Trigger and give it a playthrough.

This is a terrible turn-based RPG made with the RPG Maker engine and it's one of the worst games I've played.

I can get past the limited options and visual settings that RPG Maker games suffer from, and I can get past the generic artwork and horrible music, but this game has a horrible combat system and that I can NOT get past.

My main issue with this game is the fact that your enemies level up with you.
This is rarely used in RPGs and with good reason. It's a horrible idea that makes no sense, and makes you want to either:

1. AVOID battles at all costs to keep the enemies low level or
2. Fight in the same area leveling up to 99.

However, WHY would you want to skip battles in an RPG? Why would you want to repeat the same areas if you don't gain an advantage from grinding?
Why do the enemies level up between battles? My team hit level 10 in the first area and the same slimes and flowers were level 10 as well. It's not like they were fighting battles, and this doesn't make sense because in the first area of the game you should not have to be fighting such high level creatures.

I'm not saying this is difficult, I'm saying this is not fun and that's the most important thing.

This game is garbage for this reason, and I would suggest avoiding it no matter how cheap it goes on sale.

Edit: I've learned that it's possible things change later in the game, but based on this being the introduction to the game, I didn't want to continue. This is a very bad way to start off an RPG.

However, 25% of battles work differently: you have even worse damage, but one spell that does big damage, but enemy - it either does genocidal damage or stunlock 3/4 of your party on first move. I am writing this review as I struggle through last battle where you have ONE character at max level, which does not have any attacks that would do significant damage (except super attack which first requires drinking skill potion - to get 100 skill points for that attack, and then actually attacking, which will not happen as you will get stunned) while enemies have elemental attacks, that end your first turn by either stunning you or paralyzing. Of course, you will be dead before you can move as you can get both paralyze and stun at the same time, but they wear out not at the same time, so you get at least one of those debuffs most of your turns.
If the battle is an easy one, it will be boring. The big HP and low dmg extend battles to very long times. There is nothing else about them except that enemy lvl scales as you level up, but enemies characteristics - and that is AT LEAST agility which determines turn order and is most noticeable to this as after level up you frequently no longer attack first - grow faster. Thankfully, boss battles are of a fixed levels.
For graphics and sound - PURELY default RPG maker assets. I was unable to see anything unique in this game. The only thing that was quite good is that developer used different character faces for different emotions. Not every rpg maker game does this, so it is nice too see this small feature, especially that facial expressions go very well with a plot. But the game fails in many places, so its not really helping.
Plot is so-so. People say that its a Naruto ripoff, but I haven't watched that cartoon so can't say. But what I can say is that its too much absurd at times.

I would not recommend buying this even with 90% discount, too much bad development choices make this game true mess. But if you like CRAZY plots - you might want to check it out, but make sure that you play on easy difficulty, as last boss is still hard as hell. People say that on hard, its unbearable right from the start of the game.

Yet another jprg made with RPG maker - a tool which has made it easier for independent companies to make, produce and release games. Desteny Warriors is normal turn-based rpg with both random and defined battles. The story, which is actually quite surprisingly decent is based on the group of teenager ninja students and their adventures - sounds familiar? Well it's a Naruto inspired game alright.

Desteny Warriors has potential and the devs have done their job ok. I also digged the consistent, linear design of story - the linearness might divide opinion but I dig that I always know what to do next.

The thing which fails in the game is disturbing dialogue. I really did find the story partly great, but it is clashed with clumsy comedy, which may make you sneer awkwardly rahter than smile. If this is meant to be satire or joke I don't get it.

I don't rate this down only for trashy dialogue. The fighting gets dull after while because the fights last seriously longer time than other jrpg games I've played. The hostiles can simply take too much of damage before falling and  animations won't save the day no matter how fine they are.

In conclusion Desteny Warriors is ok rpg for its light price and I know worse ways to spent money. And if the game should get a sequel I'd love it being ripped off from all this tasteless gab and replaced with quality which actually is harmony with the rest of the game.

I want to like this game, I like Cubicle Quest, but this game, this game has so many flaws!  Also I will say that I've played way more than what it says I have since I played this mainly offline and steam does not track offline play time.  I'm currently on Chap 9 in game

-Naruto storyline

Cons
-Naruto based storyline
-Every character you can tell relatively early on is a Naruto reference and some chapters if you can't tell by then will quite literally toss that fact in your face
- There is an arbitrary level cap which you WILL hit well before the end of the game
- The enemies lv with you making relatively easy fights becoming incredibly long and tedious by the end game
- Nearly every skill is improperly coded so instead of doing realistic damage they do 1 dmg, every, time.
- There are not only random encounters when walking through a map, but roaming ones you actually see on the map, and if one of those touch you, you can't flee and when you get later on those fights can take upwards of 15 mins to complete especially on chap 8 I believe
- The cast of playable characters you can use is relatively small and out of all of them at end game you will only be using one of them (this game's version of Sakura), and one is completely useless for nearly the whole game (this game's version of Rock Lee)
- Out of all the late game skills you get only one does any consistent or notable damage which is deadly bubbles, which you will spam in EVERY FIGHT
- The music is repetitive to the extreme, This game as well as cubicle quest use the same base sound files, but there it actually sounds nice to me, here it is dull and clashes, the only song that has stuck out to me is the one where you fight all the music ninjas (the games version of the sound 5 from the Sasuke's departure arc) and that song doesn't show up till the end of chap 6 I beleive.

reviewText:
DISCLAIMER: I was given a key for free by the publisher!

First Look after 2 hrs.

Destiny Warriors RPG puts you in the boots of J.C. a young elite warrior student and member of Team Phoenix, where he teams up with 3 other students. While every character is able to use magic, every character has a special focus on either elemental magic or healing abilities.

Gameplaywise progress has been very linear so far with hardly any room for exploration. However, the combat mechanics are interesting to play around! Apart from your standard features (Attack, Guard and Items and magic, called X-TU) there are so called Skills/Moves which can be triggered after earning so called TP points while fighting. These include elemental buffs for weapons as well as a variety of special attacks. More spells and skills/moves are unlocked by leveling up.
Combat itself hasn't been too much of a challenge so far, but this is what makes Destiny Warriors RPG accessible imho.

In conclusion, I recommend Destiny Warriors RPG to newcomers to the 16-bit classic style JRPG genre, as it always keeps objectives clear and battles on the easier side, compared to other titles where you have to be your guard at all times!

PS: There is even some swearing in the game....The evil F word!!

Pretty decently made JRPG. You take the role of a ninja in training and... well. lets just say traditions are upheld here when it comes to story and setting.  You Have the tough guy, his best friend, the emo (literally named 'The emo'), the cute healer and...well. they are all there.

Engine is a newer rpgengine and it makes up for quite a lot as i can't really find anything to complain about the gameplay. it is fluid and fights are prettier and more varied than before.

Price is very low which adds to the appeal. You wont be getting anything groundbreaking for the price but this is by no means one of those 'it costs just some cents but i regret buying it anyway' -type of game.

I won't be hiding my hatred of traditional JRPG games here but i must admit this one is entertaining right from the start - despite umm... traditions. I especially liked the fact that there is more handholding in the beginning than usually so you get a pretty good headstart into things before difficulty ramps up. Another great idea in this game is to also explore the first forest area with a proper party so you get introduced to the special moves and skills you have available.

Try it,
